and engineering controls are in place at JAC-PAC. These controls are designed to eliminate, or reduce the possibilities of an accidental release from the refrigeration system.
     
1. Electronic ammonia detection installed in compressor room.  Alarm system activates a local audible alarm to alert plant personnel of the potential ammonia leak in the monitored areas.

2. High-level switches are configured to high and low pressure receivers. High-level switches will shut down compressor operation during a high level condition.

3. All compressors are configured with critical safety controls (high pressure, low pressure, high oil temp cut-outs, etc.) to shut down the respective compressor in the event of an abnormal operating condition.
 
4. Safety Relief Valves are configured to all pressure vessels, condensers and compressor oil separators to eliminate over pressurization conditions in those associated pieces of equipment.

5. Emergency system button are installed on the exterior wall to enable system shutdown from outside the room in the event of an emergency involving the ammonia system.

6. Periodic Maintenance Program is performed based on the PSM Mechanical Integrity program to ensure the refrigeration system and it's components are kept in optimum mechanical and operating status. Daily rounds are made by plant personnel to verify proper equipment operation.

4.  Five-year accident history

The Jac-Pac Foods, Ltd. facility in Manchester has had no accidental releases to report based on the RMP accidental release reporting criteria (on site or off-site deaths or injury, etc.).  There was, however, a reportable quantity (RQ) release of ammonia release on  July 11, 2000 at 1:15 AM where Anhydrous Ammonia (CAS #  7664-41-7) was estimated to be release for 30 minutes with 432 pounds of ammonia released to the atmosphere from the Cook ammonia system pressure relief valves.  Two employees were evaluated by hospital medical personnel and released. The reason for the r

are designed to change the availability of the associated energy. The refrigeration cycle is a closed loop process. The ammonia cycle utilizes fluid temperature, pressure and latent heat of vaporization for cooling. The refrigeration system uses this phenomenon to remove heat from a desired space, and then to discard that heat through condensation, to an area where it is of no consequence.

The Jac-Pac Foods, Ltd. facility uses ammonia refrigeration to maintain process rooms and warehouse cooler and freezers temperatures for various types of fresh and frozen food distributed to their customers. The refrigeration system contains the following equipment: 2 compressors, 2 evaporative condensers, 1 high pressure receiver, 1 low pressure receiver, 32 evaporators, 1 purger. The refrigeration system contains and estimated 11,000 pounds of aggregate ammonia. 

There are approximately 600 employees at this facility that include hourly and salary personnel.  This food processing operation facility receives and processes shipment of meats via tractor trailers.  Site operations run Monday through Saturday on a first and second shift.  Monday through Saturday a third shift sanitation (clean-up occurs.  Sundays are primarily for maintenance and facilities work.  Distribution operates Monday through Saturday 20 hours per day.  Cooking operations occur 24 hours a day; 7 days a week. 

The potential hazards that could lead to an accidental release of the ammonia include, but are not limited to, equipment failure, damage to piping, damage to equipment, human error, etc.
 
Although ammonia is a colorless, tasteless liquid, it's dominant characteristic is it's pungent, distinct odor.  Persons exposed to ammonia will not voluntarily stay in areas of even small concentrations, although these levels would not normally result in any health risks. Risks from accidental exposure to ammonia in a vapor state are irritations to the eyes, nose and throat. The extent of irritation depends on the

Jac Pac Foods, Ltd.
163 Hancock Street
Manchester, NH 03101
 
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.  General accidental release and prevention policy of Jac-Pac Foods, Ltd.:

In this meat processing operation, we utilize anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant.  Anhydrous ammonia is considered hazardous by the U.S Environmental Protection Agency USEPA. The same properties that make ammonia a valuable refrigerant also makes it necessary to observe certain safety precautions during it's use to prevent exposure to our workers, the surrounding community and the environment.  

It is our policy at Jac-Pac Foods, Ltd. to implement the requirements of the Risk Management Program by managing and operating this facility in full compliance with all applicable federal and state regulations that we are governed by.  The objective is to minimize the risk of an accidental release of hazardous materials.  Safety depends directly on our proper handling of ammonia.  Our plant personnel have been trained on the equipment operating procedures and the various safety devices that are incorporated in our facility to prevent the possibility of accidental releases.

As a Program Level 3 RMP facility, this site has an extensive process safety management (PSM) program and is committed to the implementation of this program and the prevention of toxic release from the Jac-Pac facility.

2.  Stationary source and regulated substance handled:

Jac-Pac Foods, Ltd., located at 163 Hancock Street, Manchester, NH operates a refrigeration system utilizing anhydrous ammonia as the primary refrigerant. Mechanical refrigeration is a thermodynamic process where the refrigerant, ammonia, is used as a heat exchanging fluid to maintain a desired temperature in an enclosed environment. The refrigeration cycle consists of evaporation, compression, condensation and expansion. Evaporation and condensation are designed to alter the quantity of energy associated with the refrigerant. Compression and expansion

exposure amount and length of time exposed.  Ammonia is classified non-flammable by the Department of Transportation.  Ammonia will burn, but only in a very narrow concentration level when accompanied with a constant ignition source.

3. Worst case  and alternate case release scenarios including administrative and engineering      controls to limit/ prevent accidental release.

Worst case scenario depicts continuous source leak from the one of the high pressure receivers (HPR) located inside the plant machinery room.  This vessels normal operating level is 3,000 pounds of liquid ammonia, although the entire system is capable of holding 11,000 pounds.  

Worst case release scenario criteria for the Jac-Pac Foods facility:

The Worst Case release scenario is represented by the release of ammonia vapor flashing from a ruptured ammonia liquid receiver (engine room is open to the outside air). 

Ammonia Quantity:3,000 pounds
Rate of Release:300 lbs / min. (10 min. release)
LOC (Level of Concern):200 ppm  (EPA ERPG-2)  
Physical State:Liquified, flashing to gas 
Type of Area: Urban
Stability Class:F
Wind Speed:1.5 m/sec
Distance to Endpoint: 0.2 miles (RMPComp)

Potential Off-Site Receptors: 128 persons in 65 housing units; one school (Bakersville School); one interstate (I-293); one river (Merrimack River); one municipal school bus service location; one college (across Queen City Ave).

Alternate case release scenario criteria for Jac-Pac Foods, Ltd. facility:

The Alternate release scenario is represented by the release of ammonia vapor from a physical damage to coil of an evaporator located within the Jac-Pac Foods facility.

Ammonia Quantity: 1000 pounds
Rate of Release: 100 pounds/min. (10 min. release)
Physical State: Liquified, flashing to gas 
Type of Area: Urban
Stability Class: D
Wind Speed: 1.5 m/sec
Distance to Endpoint: 0.1 miles  (RMPComp)

Potential Off-Site Receptors: 4 persons in 1housing units; one river (Merrimack River).

The following administrative

elease was a shorting of H Clamp on 480 Volt line; shutoff of pump and fan motors to ammonia condenser; ammonia compressors continue to run without cooling; pressure build-up in system; compressors shut down at 250psi shutoff point, except Mycon #1; At 275 Psi, relief valve released; compressor #1 also shuts down at 275 psi; Oil in center transformer ignites; Fuse on transmission pole blows.  The response actions were: Manchester Fire Department: evaluated 2 employees who had trouble breathing; taken to hospital and released; Extinguished fire and disconnected power at power pole.  Gemini Electric repaired electrical equipment;  Ammonia released dissipated without known problems. 

5.   Emergency Response Program

The purpose of the Jac-Pac Foods, Ltd. Chemical Emergency Response Plan is to:

A. Minimize exposure to our employees and the surrounding community in the event of a hazardous material release or spill.

B. Assure the safe emergency evacuation of the plant in the instance that it is required.

C. Provide for prompt medical attention to any employees who become seriously injured or ill at work.

D. Facility management has developed an Emergency Response Plan to ensure a fast and efficient response in the event of an accidental release of hazardous materials. 

Our Emergency Action Plan currently meets requirements as set forth in OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38, Employee Emergency and Fire Prevention Plans, OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 HAZWOPER written spill plan requirements, and spill prevention control and countermeasures (SPCC) plan requirements of 40 CFR 112.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

A. Completion of follow-up to Process Hazard Analyses conducted in Summer, 2001, including:

1. Consider performing vibration analysis on all compressors.
2. Consider performing oil analysis on all compressors. 
3. Replace the outdated pressure relief valves on the oil pots and repipe.
4. Review the startup and shutdown procedure for the system.
5. Consider providing refrigerat

ion training to mechanics/supervisors especially for troubleshooting and startup after a power failure.
6. Consider tagging all valves and labeling the piping on system for SOP identification. 
7. Include the ventilation system in the MI program.
8. Identify all operating parameters for system and record in files.
9. Cap or plug open piping in all parts of system.
10. Remove or LOTO all open gas flame heaters.
11. Replace the pressure safety valves on all dump tanks with new dual setups.
12. Tagout valves in R&D holding freezer.
13. Install spring loaded ball valves on the Pilot Receiver, Control Pressure Receiver, Oil Pots, Accumulators, and the Water Chiller.
14. Consider writing a description of the electrical safety systems and interlocks for the system including the ammonia detectors, alarm tie-ins to Honeywell, and ventilation fans.
15. Verify ventilation calculations for the engine room.
16. Verify the relief valve header calculations for the compressors.
17. Establish a refrigeration maintenance logbook in the compressor room.
18. Implement a contractor mechanical integrity checklist for inspections.
19. Perform calibration tests on all new ammonia detectors and record in mechanical integrity program.
20. Establish a Process Safety Information library in the engine room. 
21. Install a windsock on the condenser. 
22. Perform shutdown test for the emergency shutdown buttons.
23. Test all float switches on the vessels.
24. Test all compressor cutout limits for pressure and temperature on an annual basis. 
25. Perform a test to confirm the activation of the ventilation system by the ammonia detectors in the engine room.
26. Perform a test of the Honeywell system for ammonia alarm activation.
27. Verify operation of safeties & interlocks.
28. Install a check valve on the ammonia charge line to the high pressure receiver.

B. Continue full implementation of the Process Safety Management (PSM Program).
